qas.question: In which book of the Bible are limitations on Jewish monarchs outlined?
Who was against the divine rights of kings in England during the 1500s?
What principle did the restrictions on the right of kings, as detailed in Deuteronomy, influence later opposition?
What historical book may have a significant impact on contemporary law making practices?
According to the restrictions placed on Jewish kings in Deuteronomy, ownership over what was regulated?
Book of the viable gives unlimited power Jewish monarchs?
Who was against the divine right of kings in England during the fifteenth century?
What book of the Bible supported the divine rule of kings
What group of ancient Jews could have as many wives and horses as they wanted?

context: There has recently been an effort to reevaluate the influence of the <a3_0>Bible<a3_0/> on Western constitutional law. In the Old Testament, there was some language in <a0_0><b5_0><b7_0>Deuteronomy<b7_0/><b5_0/><a0_0/> imposing restrictions on the <b8_0>Jewish king<b8_0/>, regarding such things as how many wives he could have, and how many <a4_0>horses<a4_0/> he could own for his personal use. According to Professor Bernard M. Levinson, "This legislation was so utopian in its own time that it seems never to have been implemented...." The Deuteronomic social vision may have influenced opponents of the <a2_0>divine right of kings<a2_0/>, including <a1_0><b6_0>Bishop John Ponet<b6_0/><a1_0/> in sixteenth-century England.
